7.0	Contractors

This section applies to contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process.  It does not apply to contractors providing incidental services which do not influence process safety, such as janitorial work, food and drink services, laundry, delivery or other supply services.

CGP shall obtain and evaluate information regarding the contract employer¿s safety performance and programs.  This may include information on injury and illness rates, experience rates, and contractor references.  An injury and illness log related to the contractor¿s work in process areas will be maintained.

The contract employer shall ensure that each employee is trained to safely perform tasks, shall ensure that each employee is instructed in the known potential fire, explosion or toxic release hazards and the associated emergency action plan, training must be documented, ensure that each employee follows the rules, and shall advise the employer of any unique hazards presented by their work.

CGP has created a contractor orientation and agreement sheet to ensure all CGP obligations are met and carried out.  More details about these items can be found in the Contractor Orientation and Approval procedure.  

8.0	Pre-Startup Safety Review

Pre-Startup safety reviews (PSR) shall be performed on new and/or modified facilities and/or processes that require a change in the process safety information.  The pre-startup safety review shall take place

d space entry procedures as indicated in section 5.0 of this plan.    

11.0	Management of Change

Management of change (MOC) has been established to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment (except for `replacement in kind¿), procedures and changes to facilities that affect the covered process.  Details of MOC can be found in the MOC program in the Procedure Manual.

12.0	Incident Investigation

Incident Investigations are performed to determine the root cause(s) of incidents in order to prevent future occurrences.  All incidents will be promptly investigated and documented following the incident.  Time is of the essence when performing incident investigations.  Facts can be confused over time.  

Employees involved in the incident will be interviewed to obtain as much information as possible.  Cooperation of employees is essential to the investigation.  The focus is to find facts, not to place blame.  

All resolutions and corrective actions will be documented on the report.  The incident investigation reports will be retained.  See the Incident Investigation Program for more details.

13.0	Emergency Planning and Response

CGP has developed an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP).  This plan includes emergency planning and response procedures.  It includes emergencies such as bomb threats, severe weather, evacuation, fire/explosion, etc.  All employees are trained according to their responsibility when hired and annually thereafter.  Drills will also be conducted to verify the effectiveness of the program and to ensure employee understanding.  See the ICP for more details.

14.0	Compliance Audits

CGP will use compliance audits as a technique to gather sufficient facts and information to verify compliance.  A team will be used perform audits of this program.  Theses audits will be conducted every 3 years.

The team will be selected based on their knowledge, experience and training.  The audit will compare what is actually done with the written PSM/R

MP program.  It may include a review of relevant documentation, inspection of the facility, and interviews with plant personnel.  The interviews will assist in determining the effectiveness of training and assessing the knowledge of the employee.  The written program may be evaluated for adequacy of content, frequency of training, effectiveness of training in terms of its goals and objectives as well as how it fits into meeting the programs requirements.  

The audit will be documented.  It will include the areas audited, deficiencies, and corrective actions.  If necessary the PSM/RMP program will be updated.  Audit records can be found in Appendix 8.

15.0	Trade Secrets

Several processes and materials with fall into the areas of trade secrets as set forth in OSHA 1910.119(p), especially information listed in Section 3.0.  CGP may require team members and those working on-site to sign confidentiality agreements (CA).  See the confidentiality agreement program for more details.

Trade secret information shall be made available to team members involved in the process safety information process, plant operations, and incident investigations.  It shall also be made available to anyone involved in emergency planning and emergency response and compliance audits.  Receiving this information require signing a CA.

Process Safety Management (PSM) & Risk Management Plan (RMP)

Purpose ¿ The purpose of this document is to provide instruction for Berggruen BioFuels Holdings, LLC* and its subsidiaries to prevent and/or minimize the consequences of unwanted and catastrophic releases of hazardous chemicals especially into locations that could expose employees and the surrounding communities to serious hazards. 
Responsibility ¿ Management is responsible for ensuring all aspects of the PSM/RMP program are implemented and carried out.  Supervisors and Employees must be familiar with and have an understanding of the hazards, operating procedures, safety systems, start-up procedures, shutdown procedures, training contractor involvement, maintenance, emergency planning, and emergency response.

Change Notes ¿ 

Rev. 01 ¿05/20/2008 ¿ Original Release.

Definitions
	
1.0	Catastrophic release ¿ a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion, involving one or more highly hazardous chemicals, that presents serious danger to employees in the workplace.
2.0	Facility ¿ the buildings, containers, or equipment which contains a process.
3.0	Highly hazardous chemical ¿ a substance possessing toxic, reactive, flammable, or explosive properties.  Over 10,000 pounds of a flammable liquid or gas, and/or listed in 29 CFR 1910.199, App. A or 40 CFR 68.130, App. A.
4.0	Process ¿ any activity involving a highly hazardous chemical including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or the on-site movement of such chemicals, or combination of these activities.  For purposes of this definition, any group of vessels which are interconnected and separate vessels which are located such that a highly hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release shall be considered a single process.

1.0	Introduction to PSM/RMP
			
This program applies to any process that involves a chemical at or above the specific threshold quantities list in Appendix A of 29 CFR 1910.119 (PSM) or Appendix A of 40 CFR 68.130 (RMP).  

Process Safety Management (PSM)

According to 29 CFR 1910.119, a PSM is required for facilities which have a process that involves a flammable liquid or gas on-site in one location, in a quantity of 10,000 pounds or more and is not a hydrocarbon solely used for work place consumption as a fuel, or is stored in an atmospheric tank that is kept below the boiling point without the benefit of chilling or refrigeration.  

Ethanol, natural gasoline and denatured ethanol are defined as flammable liquids.  The storage of flammable liquids in atmospheric tanks is exempt from coverage; however the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) has indicated that accidents involving flammable liquids would be investigated under the general duty clause.  Manufacturing processes that store or use greater than 10,000 pounds of a flammable liquid are covered.  The distillation, dehydration and evaporation portion of the CGP process contains greater than 10,000 pounds of ethanol, a flammable substance. 

Solutions with ammonia content greater than 44 percent and in a quantity greater than 15,000 pounds are regulated under the PSM standard.  The facility is also subject to regulations under EPA RMP 40 CFR Part 68 (see below) and meets the Program 3 eligibility requirements.  One of the requirements of a facility subject to Program 3 is to conduct a PSM review of the covered process.

Risk Management Plan (RMP)

According to 40 CFR Part 68, a RMP is required for facilities that co

ntain more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process, as determined under Part 68.115.  Cascade Grain Products (CGP) stores more than the 20,000 pound threshold of aqueous ammonia with a concentration greater than 20%, which is an RMP regulated substance.  Aqueous Ammonia is the only RMP regulated substance.

2.0	Employee Participation

It is CGP¿s desire to assure full participation in the PSM and RMP.  This involvement will lead to a better understanding by all of the hazards, operating procedures, safety systems, start-up procedures, shut-down procedures, contractor involvement, maintenance, emergency planning and emergency response necessary to implement a full and complete program.  

This program will be available to each employee to ensure they are consulted in the development of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and all other aspects of this program.  Upon request, they will also be given access to the PHA¿s and other information required under this standard.  An agreement explaining this information will be provided to each employee.  This letter will be signed, returned to the HR/Safety Manager and kept in Appendix 1.  

A safety committee has been created and may be available to assist with any aspect of this program.

3.0	Process Safety Information

Process safety information shall include information pertaining chemical hazards, technology, and equipment.

3.1	Chemical Hazard Information

Chemical hazard information shall include information pertaining to hazards of the highly hazardous chemicals used or produced by the process, and the information pertaining to the equipment in the process.  Information pertaining to highly hazardous chemicals in the process shall consist of toxicity information, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reactivity data, corrosivity data, thermal and chemical stability data, and hazardous effect of mixing different materials.  

The chemicals for the CGP facility that apply, but are not limited

to, ammonia, natural gasoline, ethanol and denatured ethanol.  The Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for these chemicals can be found in Appendix 2.

3.2	Technology Information

Technology information shall include information on the following:

o	Process Flow Diagram ¿ See Appendix 3.
o	Process Chemistry or Brief description of the process ¿ See Appendix 4.
o	Maximum Intended Inventory ¿ Basically, this is limited to highly hazardous chemicals as required by OSHA. 
o	Safe Upper and Lower Limits ¿ This information can be found in the standard operating guidelines and/or operating manuals created by CGP and provided by the design engineer.
o	Consequences of Deviations ¿ These consequences have been determined for safety, and most quality and environmental purposes during the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP).

3.3	Equipment Information

Equipment information shall include information on the following:
o	Materials of Construction ¿ This has been determined by the design company.  Manuals and specification sheet for most of the equipment has been provided.  Other drawings, such as P&ID¿s, may have additional details.
o	Piping & Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID¿s) ¿ All available drawings can be found in the Administration Building.  They will be used to assist in the analysis, troubleshooting and quality assurance of our systems.
o	Electrical Classification ¿ These classifications are made to ensure the equipment is properly operated and isolated from flammable hazard along with meeting the NFPA class codes.
o	Relief System Design & Design Basis ¿ These systems are intended to be one of the last lines of defense against rupture of equipment due to excessive pressure.  Information on these systems may be found in the maintenance management systems or in the P&ID¿s.
o	Ventilation Design¿ These may be documented within P&ID¿s or within the maintenance management system.
o	Design Codes & Standard Employed ¿ These may be documented within P&ID¿s or within the maintenance

management system.
o	Mass & Energy Balances ¿ See Appendix 5 for details.
o	Safety Systems ¿ These systems consist of interlocks, detection or suppression systems.  Most of the details for this system can be found in the P&ID¿s.

4.0	Process Hazard Analysis

An initial process hazard analysis (PHA) on these processes has been performed.  The PHA was appropriate to the complexity of the process and has identified, evaluated, and controlled the hazards involved.  The methodology used for the initial PHA was a Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP).  See Appendix 6 for details.

The PHA is designed to analyze the possible causes and consequences of fires, explosions, releases of toxic chemicals, and major spills of hazardous chemicals.  We shall focus on the equipment, instrumentation, utilities, human actions (routine and non-routine) and external factors that might effect the process.

At least every 5 years after completion of the initial PHA, the PHA shall be updated and revalidated by a team meeting the qualifications as determined by this program to assure that the PHA is consistent with the current process.  For this update, one or more of the following methodologies can be used, as appropriate:
o	What-if
o	Checklist
o	What-if Checklist
o	Hazard and operability study (HAZOP)
o	Failure mode and effects analysis
o	Fault tree analysis

These procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure they reflect the current practice.  They will be certified annually.  This certification will be reflected with a revision date and/or signature and date.  

Safe work practices have been developed and implemented to provide for the control of hazards during operations.  These practices shall apply to both the employees and contracted employees.  Some of the safe work practices include lockout/tagout, confined space entry, line breaking, and access.  All of these can be found on the server and/or in the procedures manual.  

6.0	Training

Each employee involved in the operating process will be trained in an overview of the process and in standard operating procedures.  In addition, employees will be trained on safe work practices, emergency evacuation, safety procedures, routing and non-routine work authorization activities, confined space entry, LOTOTO, and many other areas as necessary to protect the employee and process.

Training may be conducted with different techniques such as hands-on, classroom, on-the-job, video programs, written materials, and any other technique to provide clear and effective training.  Employees may be tested in some areas to ensure their competence and knowledge of the area.

Refresher training shall be provided as determined.  CGP wants to ensure that the employee involved understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process.  Formal and information evaluation of

It also my enlist contractor assistance in this process.  The size and structure of the team may also vary based on the complexity of the PSR. 9.0	Mechanical Integrity

Mechanical Integrity applies to several types of process equipment including pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems (including piping components such as valves), relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls (including monitoring devices and sensors, alarms, and interlocks), an

d pumps.  For each of this process equipment, inspections and testing, training, maintenance, and quality assurance will be performed.

To manage the mechanical integrity, a maintenance management system will be used.  The functions of the this system will include the equipment ID #¿s, procedures/frequency of preventive maintenance in accordance with manufacturer¿s instruction, documenting deficiencies and corrective actions, documenting inspections and testing, controlling spare parts inventory, and the ability to evaluate trends for troubleshooting purposes.  A set of manuals will be kept for each piece of equipment, where available.

Each inspection and test performed on process equipment will be documented in the maintenance management system.  This will include the date of the inspection or test, the name of the person who performed the inspection or test, the serial or equipment ID #, a description of the inspection or test performed, the results, and criteria for acceptable test results.  

Each employee involved in the maintenance of this equipment will be properly trained.  This training will consist of an overview of the process and its hazards and in the procedure applicable to the employee¿s task to assure they can perform the tasks in a safe manner.

For Quality Assurance purposes, process equipment will be checked to assure it is suitable for the process application for which it is used including spare parts.  This information will also be documented within the maintenance management system.
